children.subject: You can ask the TA's if you can do the graduate level work associated with 289, if you want. But you will be taking 189.
CS 289A (can I take the grad level course for grad school units?) No you can't..
+1. Strongly recommends 170 over 100 for your purpose.

I read from previous posts that benefits from 170 can be easily simulated by grinding leetcode; however, I recently realized that 168 is only available in the Fall, so would you suggest me to replace 168 for 170?

I believe that classes like 70 and 170 will train your mental ability tremendously. I believe the OP for that post might have argued that in terms of interview preps, leetcode is sufficient because well you code during technical interviews. However, I still think 170 is fundamental for anyone interested in a CS career. 168 is kind of a narrow field whereas 170 will teach you concepts that will be a theme throughout your cs career. It is a pretty obvious choice. 170 over 168 unless you want to work in the networking industry.
even 168 uses ideas in 170... just saying.

170 is certainly not necessary for technical interviews, but it is a fun class and will serve you better than 100. You certainly can get far into your career without needing anything from 170(Assuming you do interview prep), but it's a fun class and you'll learn about cool Algorithms.

It can be a demanding class so in certain cases, I wouldn't recommend it to people. However, your schedules every semester seem chill, so you should take 170. Don't take data 100.

170 is pretty useless imo. Just grind leetcode (especially the DP and greedy problems) and you'll be golden and never have to worry about having to deal with all the theory bs on the side that 170 tries to force upon you. Unless that's your cup of tea, would highly recommend against 170.
Also I personally really liked Data 100, so that's why I would recommend against swapping with 170.

This person is correct that 170 is pretty much useless, and 61B provides enough education so you can self study 170. I personally didn't like 100, but if you're looking to take a breadth of CS courses, go ahead and take 100.

If I weren't to take Data 100 or Data 8, what other statistics / data science course should I take in this summer?

I posted an updated course plan in the below answer if you guys want to advise me in where I should put CS 170 in my schedule.
seems very doable. based on ur interests, I'd recommend swapping data 100 for cs 170 since cs 170 is more useful for SWE interviews

130 unit cap - 70 units transferred = 60 units left

If I take 8 units in the summer and 13 each quarter, I don't have enough for a 5th semester. 

I'd like to just take Data 100 but the prerequisite is Data 8. Based on the advice, I'll probably forgo taking those two classes, but I'd still want to gain some foundation in statistics/data science either through another course or self-study. 

Yeah, I'd like to take CS 61B if I had another semester, but since I don't, I'll try my best to finish all the projects and watch all the videos over the summer. 

I'll take your advice and take both CS 61A and 61C this Fall. I actually don't even need to EE 16B until senior, but I was thinking about just getting it done so delaying that to Spring seems fine.

My new course plan as of now is:

Summer 2019:

CS 70

Data 8 / Data 100 (if possible) / or something else

relearn EE 16A and CS 61B material

 

Fall 2019:

CS 61A

CS 61C

 

Spring 2020:

EE 16B

CS 162 - this is the prerequisite to CS 168

 

Summer 2020:

internship or research (hopefully)

 

Fall 2020:

CS 168 - I think this is only available in the Fall

CS 186

 

Spring 2021 - Graduate:

CS 161

CS 189

Where should I put CS 170? Or, should I at all? It seems like the above answers think its worth the trouble of extra theory.

Many of you mentioned how my schedule each semester is "chill." I agree - that was my intention as I want to focus on deeply learning the material as well as being extremely active on campus with the time I have left. I wanted to take advantage of the fact that I literally just need to finish my major courses (and hit the 120 unit mark.)
I think the best way to fit is to take CS 70 and CS 61A together this summer and CS 61C and CS 170 in Fall 2019.

You might be eligible for 5 semesters btw depending on # of units.

Summer 2019: Cool, although tbh you don't need data 8. Just take data 100.

Fall 2019: tbh I recommend retaking 61B at Cal, it's a fantastic course. But you probably won't, so this schedule is fine and if you have interview prepped like leetcode and cracking coding interview, then yes you're ready and should apply during fall. Put your Community College GPA on your resume, say you're a junior, you can tell them you're a transfer, they shouldn't care unless they're assholes, and you'll be good to go! 

Spring 2020: Ya that's a chill schedule, although i'd rather take 61c with Dan Garcia, and I think he's teaching in fall. You should take 61a and 61c together in fall tbh then take 16b and 100 in spring.

Fall 2020: This is going to be a heavy load. 162 you don't need to take it, better to self study, but if you will take it, do 168 and 162 instead.

Spring 2021: 186 is a heavy load. Your hardest courses on this list are 162, 189, 186. The rest are chill. Keep that in mind. Take 186 your first year, you don't need any pre req except for Java experience.

Also AFAIK, aside from C100 which I heard is enforcing the prereqs to take the class, most every CS upper div doesn't enforce prereqs. E.g. you definitely don't need to take 162 before 168, they only overlap very slightly and aren't really related in any way that would suggest that 162 is crucial to your understanding of 168.

Not sure if you already planned your upper div tech elective units outside of this schedule, but one thing you could do to solve your 170 vs C100 dilemma is to do both and use the units from the extra class toward your tech elective units. I graduated last semester with the same upper div classes as you, with the addition of 170 and 188 for my tech elective units. You could probably throw 170 in either Fall 2019 or Spring 2020 for easiest workload with the rest of your classes. IMO Spring 2020 would be easier to fit it in since 16B is a lower div and 162 is more project heavy than pset heavy.

186 = Difficult projects but not difficult code. You have to study large files of code and they take time and thought. A bad class to take with other techs because you will rush, and the projects are hard when you're rushing. The 3rd and 5th Project take a while to think about the solutions. The 1st, 2nd, and 4th are not trivial, but can be rushed. The material and lectures are very dry and boring, with tons of information(with very little break in-between concepts during videos). I appreciate the material and the projects though, and find it interesting how database systems work, even if they are a bit complicated. Not useful in many Software Engineering jobs.

161 = Excellent course, and a great intro for someone interested in security. Projects are very chill(not easy, require lots of thought, but not much code and can certainly be rushed). Well run with excellent staff and professors who care a lot. The work comes in bursts, which is nice because there's plenty of time to study the material. The first month can seem a bit hectic, but it dies around around month 1.5. Tests are fair, not easy, but if you study a lot, you should expect to get at least 1 std below, which may seem bad, but can reassure people who are afraid of failing. To do well in the course, that comes down to understanding concepts and doing practice exams.

168 = Not much work at all, but really fascinating learning how the Internet works. Only 2 projects, took me 1-3 days each, and you have about 3 weeks to complete them. Very easy material to digest, and thus tests can be a bit tricky at times, but most people get high scores and the curve is a little less forgiving. Nevertheless, if you bomb tests, you'll still most likely pass. To do well, it will require a lot of studying since many people do well.

100 = Just wasn't interested in Data Science the more I studied the course. The work was quite boring and labs were boring for me as well.

170 = I think some of the problems were just so difficult and I didn't gain much from sitting there confused for hours. I think I would have just enjoyed spending a semester in a class called "Cracking Coding Interview and Leetcode" rather than doing 170. The project was really hard for me as well. I ended up just reading the book and doing practice exam problems and did very well.

188 = The projects are boring, and so are the homeworks. It would be nice if they just had 1-2 big projects that weren't fill in the blank, and no homeworks. The class is curved anyways, and people get 100% on hws and projects, so i'd rather just have the exams as our grade. The material is interesting, but I find most of my time is spent on the boring work.
To add to my reply, 161 and 168 are also not super useful in industry, unless you want to go into their fields. Regardless, i'm really happy I took all 3.

I think this is getting into the territory of "there's no bad answer". Read the descriptions, and take the class you think are most interesting. You can ask us if certain classes are actually useful, and the answer, will usually be it's nice to know, may be applicable in certain fields, can easily be learned on your own, and is either fun/not fun. For example, someone may love 188 material, but the class itself is quite boring to me.

186, 161, 168 were my favorite upper divs. 100, 170, 188 were my least favorite.

history.content: Looks like you received some good feedback, so marking as resolved. Your schedule looks quite reasonable to me, except that Summer 2019 will be quite busy.

As a transfer student, I wasn't sure if my schedule would prepare me enough for future SWE positions, but I tried my best to research the classes. I'd be glad if you guys gave recommendations moving around or changing the CS courses that I have planned.

Courses completed through junior college: Math 1A, 1B, 53, 54, 55; CS 61B; finished all the non-major requirements

Summer 2019:

CS 70

CS C8

relearn EE 16A and CS 61B material

Fall 2019:

CS 61A

EE 16B

Spring 2020:

CS 61C

CS C100

Summer 2020:

internship or research (hopefully - will I be prepared?)

Fall 2020:

CS 161

CS 162

Spring 2021 - Graduate:

CS 168

CS 186

CS 289A (can I take the grad level course for grad school units?)
